segment.source: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings
segment.target: Windows Phone Silverlight to UWP namespace and class mappings

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.
segment.target: This topic provides a comprehensive mapping of Windows Phone Silverlight APIs to their Universal Windows Platform (UWP) equivalents.

segment.source: There is generally not a one-to-one mapping of functionality, though: either platform may have more or less functionality than its counterpart in a namespace or class.
segment.target: There is generally not a one-to-one mapping of functionality, though: either platform may have more or less functionality than its counterpart in a namespace or class.

segment.source: The mapping table will help you when you're working in a UWP project and you're re-using source code from a Windows Phone Silverlight project.
segment.target: The mapping table will help you when you're working in a UWP project and you're re-using source code from a Windows Phone Silverlight project.

segment.source: There are differences in the names of namespaces and classes (including UI controls) between the two platforms.
segment.target: There are differences in the names of namespaces and classes (including UI controls) between the two platforms.

segment.source: In many cases, it's as easy as changing a namespace name and then your code will compile.
segment.target: In many cases, it's as easy as changing a namespace name and then your code will compile.

segment.source: Sometimes, a class or API name has changed as well as the namespace name.
segment.target: Sometimes, a class or API name has changed as well as the namespace name.

segment.source: Other times, the mapping takes a bit more work, and in rare cases requires a change in approach.
segment.target: Other times, the mapping takes a bit more work, and in rare cases requires a change in approach.

segment.source: *How to use the table: * First, search for the name of the class you're using.
segment.target: *How to use the table: * First, search for the name of the class you're using.

segment.source: Classes are listed whenever the mapping is more complicated than simply changing the namespace name.
segment.target: Classes are listed whenever the mapping is more complicated than simply changing the namespace name.

segment.source: If your class is not listed, then the mapping is just a namespace change.
segment.target: If your class is not listed, then the mapping is just a namespace change.

segment.source: So, find your class's namespace name and you'll find the equivalent UWP namespace name.
segment.target: So, find your class's namespace name and you'll find the equivalent UWP namespace name.

segment.source: Your class will be in that namespace.
segment.target: Your class will be in that namespace.

segment.source: If your namespace is not listed, then its name has not changed.
segment.target: If your namespace is not listed, then its name has not changed.

segment.source: Note Windows 10 supports much more of the .NET Framework than a Windows Phone Store app does.
segment.target: Note Windows 10 supports much more of the .NET Framework than a Windows Phone Store app does.

segment.source: For example, Windows 10 has several System.ServiceModel.\* namespaces as well as System.Net, System.Net.NetworkInformation, and System.Net.Sockets.
segment.target: For example, Windows 10 has several System.ServiceModel.\* namespaces as well as System.Net, System.Net.NetworkInformation, and System.Net.Sockets.

segment.source: Also, in a Windows 10 app, you will benefit from .NET Native, which an ahead-of-time compilation technology that converts MSIL into natively-runnable machine code.
segment.target: Also, in a Windows 10 app, you will benefit from .NET Native, which an ahead-of-time compilation technology that converts MSIL into natively-runnable machine code.

segment.source: .NET Native apps start faster, use less memory, and use less battery than their MSIL counterparts.
segment.target: .NET Native apps start faster, use less memory, and use less battery than their MSIL counterparts.

segment.source: Microsoft.Phone.Scheduler.PeriodicTask, ScheduledAction, ScheduledActionService, ScheduledTask , ScheduledTaskAgent classes
segment.target: Microsoft.Phone.Scheduler.PeriodicTask, ScheduledAction, ScheduledActionService, ScheduledTask , ScheduledTaskAgent classes

segment.source: (MPU = Microsoft.Phone.UserData) MPU.Account, ContactAddress, ContactCompanyInformation, ContactEmailAddress, ContactPhoneNumber classes
segment.target: (MPU = Microsoft.Phone.UserData) MPU.Account, ContactAddress, ContactCompanyInformation, ContactEmailAddress, ContactPhoneNumber classes

segment.source: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library are built into the default Styles of the common controls.
segment.target: Animations from the Windows Runtime animation library are built into the default Styles of the common controls.

segment.source: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.
segment.target: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.

segment.source:
**ItemsWrapGrid**
and **WrapGrid** can be used in the items panel template of an items control.
segment.target:
**ItemsWrapGrid**
and **WrapGrid** can be used in the items panel template of an items control.

segment.source: For more details, see Device status.
segment.target: For more details, see Device status.

segment.source: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.
segment.target: No direct equivalent for general layout purposes.

segment.source:
**ItemsWrapGrid**
and **WrapGrid** can be used in the items panel template of an items control.
segment.target:
**ItemsWrapGrid**
and **WrapGrid** can be used in the items panel template of an items control.

segment.source: As a workaround, use conditional compilation and define a custom symbol.
segment.target: As a workaround, use conditional compilation and define a custom symbol.

segment.source: Or you may be able to engineer a workaround using the IsAttached property.
segment.target: Or you may be able to engineer a workaround using the IsAttached property.

segment.source: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.\* namespaces, XNA Framework Class Library, Content Pipeline Class Library
segment.target: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.\* namespaces, XNA Framework Class Library, Content Pipeline Class Library

segment.source: In general, use Microsoft DirectX with C++.
segment.target: In general, use Microsoft DirectX with C++.

segment.source: See Developing games and DirectX and XAML interop.
segment.target: See Developing games and DirectX and XAML interop.

segment.source: Microsoft.Phone.Tasks.ConnectionSettingsTask, MarketplaceHubTask, MarketplaceReviewTask, MarketplaceSearchTask, MediaPlayerLauncher, SearchTask, SmsComposeTask, WebBrowserTask classes
segment.target: Microsoft.Phone.Tasks.ConnectionSettingsTask, MarketplaceHubTask, MarketplaceReviewTask, MarketplaceSearchTask, MediaPlayerLauncher, SearchTask, SmsComposeTask, WebBrowserTask classes

segment.source: Still supported, but some properties are missing (for example, IsReadOnly)
segment.target: Still supported, but some properties are missing (for example, IsReadOnly)

segment.source: System.Net.DownloadProgressChangedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient
segment.target: System.Net.DownloadProgressChangedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient

segment.source: Derive from System.Net.Http.StreamContent to measure progress.
segment.target: Derive from System.Net.Http.StreamContent to measure progress.

segment.source: These classes are still supported, but some properties are missing.
segment.target: These classes are still supported, but some properties are missing.

segment.source: Partial support, but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.
segment.target: Partial support, but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.

segment.source: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.
segment.target: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.

segment.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
segment.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

segment.source: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.
segment.target: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.

segment.source: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage to represent an HTTP response.
segment.target: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage to represent an HTTP response.

segment.source: Still supported, except for the constructor.
segment.target: Still supported, except for the constructor.

segment.source: System.Net.OpenReadCompletedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient
segment.target: System.Net.OpenReadCompletedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient

segment.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
segment.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

segment.source: Still supported, but use the SocketErrorCode property instead of ErrorCode.
segment.target: Still supported, but use the SocketErrorCode property instead of ErrorCode.

segment.source: System.Net.UploadProgressChangedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient
segment.target: System.Net.UploadProgressChangedEventArgs class, and similar classes related to System.Net.WebClient

segment.source: Partial support (a different set of properties), but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.
segment.target: Partial support (a different set of properties), but the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.

segment.source: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.
segment.target: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage to represent an HTTP request.

segment.source: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().
segment.target: Still supported, but use Dispose() instead of Close().

segment.source: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.
segment.target: But, the recommended, forward-looking alternative is the **HttpClient** class (or System.Net.Http.HttpClient.

segment.source: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage to represent an HTTP response.
segment.target: These APIs use System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage to represent an HTTP response.

segment.source: A custom method that returns the appropriate type.
segment.target: A custom method that returns the appropriate type.

segment.source: See Reflection in the .NET Framework for Windows Store Apps.
segment.target: See Reflection in the .NET Framework for Windows Store Apps.

segment.source: See Creating and retrieving resources in Windows Runtime apps.
segment.target: See Creating and retrieving resources in Windows Runtime apps.

segment.source: (MPSh = Microsoft.Phone.Shell) MPSh.CycleTileData, MPSh.FlipTileData, MPSh.IconicTileData, MPSh.ShellTileData, MPSh.StandardTileData classes
segment.target: (MPSh = Microsoft.Phone.Shell) MPSh.CycleTileData, MPSh.FlipTileData, MPSh.IconicTileData, MPSh.ShellTileData, MPSh.StandardTileData classes

segment.source: Still supported, but use ReadAsync() and WriteAsync() instead of BeginRead()/EndRead() and BeginWrite()/EndWrite().
segment.target: Still supported, but use ReadAsync() and WriteAsync() instead of BeginRead()/EndRead() and BeginWrite()/EndWrite().
